snippet.textDisplay: I wanna start by saying that this is a really really solid video and this is my second time around watching it when I write this, cause I liked it so much. HOWEVER, I am SO SICK of videos about Avatar open with "Remember Avatar? I bet you don't, it blew up and now no one cares anymore, so." PEOPLE REMEMBER AVATAR, MAN. Disney won't let us forget, the media won't let us forget, and youtube videos like this one won't let us forget. I really wish this hadn't opened like that, but I still love this video. But Avatar has been made virtually impossible to forget over the past 3-4 years.
snippet.textOriginal: I wanna start by saying that this is a really really solid video and this is my second time around watching it when I write this, cause I liked it so much. Disney won't let us forget, the media won't let us forget, and youtube videos like this one won't let us forget. I really wish this hadn't opened like that, but I still love this video. snippet.textDisplay: I had no idea how much work got cut from the final score, that's depressing... I loved this movie when it came out tbh but I agree that it could have been so, so much more. I did notice the score was structured super similarly to that of Titanic-- the constant use of certain motifs and using the music specifically to pull emotion from the audience-- and honestly, that shit TOTALLY works on Western audiences, so I get why Cameron played it safe there. I just wish we got to hear more of the authentic stuff. There is a piece in Disney's Dinosaur that did essentially the same thing as Avatar's score as a whole-- it's called The Courtship, I believe. It's during a scene that is clearly meant to be a traditional/cultural courtship ritual among the lemurs, and because the culture is prehistoric primates they did the same sort of thing-- blended non-western sounds and instruments and languages to get something ambiguously exotic sounding. It's a beautiful piece and one of my favorites in that score, but still definitely fits the "what Western audiences think non-Western music sounds like" trope. Tbh, Dinosaur has the same kind of ironic legacy as Avatar-- a CRAPTON of pre-production work, a HUGE budget, a SUPER ambitious technological idea at the time (implementing cgi characters onto live action backgrounds with practical visual effects overlayed onto it, as well)... and a super forgettable, lackluster story. One of Disney's most expensive movies to date I believe...
snippet.textOriginal: I had no idea how much work got cut from the final score, that's depressing... I loved this movie when it came out tbh but I agree that it could have been so, so much more. I did notice the score was structured super similarly to that of Titanic-- the constant use of certain motifs and using the music specifically to pull emotion from the audience-- and honestly, that shit TOTALLY works on Western audiences, so I get why Cameron played it safe there. I just wish we got to hear more of the authentic stuff. There is a piece in Disney's Dinosaur that did essentially the same thing as Avatar's score as a whole-- it's called The Courtship, I believe. It's during a scene that is clearly meant to be a traditional/cultural courtship ritual among the lemurs, and because the culture is prehistoric primates they did the same sort of thing-- blended non-western sounds and instruments and languages to get something ambiguously exotic sounding. It's a beautiful piece and one of my favorites in that score, but still definitely fits the "what Western audiences think non-Western music sounds like" trope. Tbh, Dinosaur has the same kind of ironic legacy as Avatar-- a CRAPTON of pre-production work, a HUGE budget, a SUPER ambitious technological idea at the time (implementing cgi characters onto live action backgrounds with practical visual effects overlayed onto it, as well)... and a super forgettable, lackluster story. One of Disney's most expensive movies to date I believe...

snippet.textDisplay:
Well all of this is based on the assumption that Cameron is a greedy fuck that made Avatar just for money.
And if that's the narrative that you believe, fine.
But what I believe is, Cameron wanted a totally alien sounded soundtrack to go with the movie, but then when he got it, he couldn't figure out how to mesh it with the film. So to solve this problem - among the countless other problems that crop up for productions this big and complicated - he made the call to play it safer so the movie can be FINISHED.
He put out his pocket money to finish Titanic when it went over budget, and sold his T1 script for a buck just so he could direct it.
So yeah he's a Hollywood white dick who steals other people's shit to make money.

snippet.textDisplay: Ah, my friend. Welcome, Sideways, to the world of Youtube linguistics nerds. I've been waiting for you. By the way, that sound was not a velar ejective. Its a voiceless uvular stop. In the International Phoentic Alphabet, we represent that as a /q/. To describe it to an English speaker, I would say... whereas the sound /k/ is at the front of the roof of the mouth, the sound /q/ is in the back.
snippet.textOriginal: Ah, my friend. Welcome, Sideways, to the world of Youtube linguistics nerds. I've been waiting for you. By the way, that sound was not a velar ejective. Its a voiceless uvular stop. In the International Phoentic Alphabet, we represent that as a /q/. To describe it to an English speaker, I would say... whereas the sound /k/ is at the front of the roof of the mouth, the sound /q/ is in the back.

snippet.textDisplay:
As a songwriter I'll try to explain what I got from "an elliptical time signature". Time Signature are those numbers you usually see at the start of music scores. The common time signature (in THIS case, we use something like a C for "common") is 4/4, wich means four beats of a quarter. Therefore, all compasses are divided in 4 beats. But there is 3/4 ("the waltz signature" - three beats of a quarter) and an endless plethora of time signatures (such as 12/8 and some that use square and cubic roots, usually used in modern classical music). An "elliptical" time signature is probably a time signature, let's call it this way, "broken", so the end of a compass or a section demands the start of that very same compass or section, therefore turning the music somehow circular, wich is, funny enough, a trope associated with tribal and/or indigenous music, from the pre-columbian Latin America to the people of Scandinavia.


Did I make myself AT LEAST clear enought?
snippet.textOriginal:
As a songwriter I'll try to explain what I got from "an elliptical time signature". Time Signature are those numbers you usually see at the start of music scores. The common time signature (in THIS case, we use something like a C for "common") is 4/4, wich means four beats of a quarter. Therefore, all compasses are divided in 4 beats. But there is 3/4 ("the waltz signature" - three beats of a quarter) and an endless plethora of time signatures (such as 12/8 and some that use square and cubic roots, usually used in modern classical music). An "elliptical" time signature is probably a time signature, let's call it this way, "broken", so the end of a compass or a section demands the start of that very same compass or section, therefore turning the music somehow circular, wich is, funny enough, a trope associated with tribal and/or indigenous music, from the pre-columbian Latin America to the people of Scandinavia. 


Did I make myself AT LEAST clear enought?

snippet.textDisplay:
I feel like we’re desperately starved for “true alienness” in media. Most “aliens” we see are just humans with makeup and MAYBE extra/missing fingers or extra/missing limbs. I get why, but I’m tired of seeing the same thing over and over again standing in for something that, in reality, should be completely unrecognisable to us humans. I think as CGI has gotten easier to pull off, we’ve been seeing more alien aliens, but that’s only one part of it. I’m devastated we didn’t get to hear this music. I’m devastated Avatar didn’t get to be what the creatives envisioned, because ultimately, I think this should have been a project that bent the rules of Hollywood movies.

But hey, at least the wyvern thingies look awesome (I’m one of the three people who hasn’t seen Avatar, sorry).
snippet.textOriginal:
I feel like we’re desperately starved for “true alienness” in media. Most “aliens” we see are just humans with makeup and MAYBE extra/missing fingers or extra/missing limbs. I get why, but I’m tired of seeing the same thing over and over again standing in for something that, in reality, should be completely unrecognisable to us humans. I think as CGI has gotten easier to pull off, we’ve been seeing more alien aliens, but that’s only one part of it. I’m devastated we didn’t get to hear this music. I’m devastated Avatar didn’t get to be what the creatives envisioned, because ultimately, I think this should have been a project that bent the rules of Hollywood movies.

But hey, at least the wyvern thingies look awesome (I’m one of the three people who hasn’t seen Avatar, sorry).

snippet.textDisplay: -“You're on adrenaline or something?” As a composer I feel that the director couldn't trust James Horner. That was one of the reasons why they did split in '86 after Aliens. I thought maybe when Titanic was done that Cameron would've learnt his lesson to trust the composer. But shooting down 90% of Horner's ideas, gives a sour taste in my mouth. Cameron knows film-making but doesn't understand music-making. It is a beginner's mistake not to think about music until the absolute last minute. Then they say they don't have money for it and chickened out with some cheap shit. Film-makers, please understand our craft, but we don't expect you to be experts. Our job is to make you feel comfortable and  that our job is to help supporting the story.
snippet.textOriginal: -“You're on adrenaline or something?” As a composer I feel that the director couldn't trust James Horner. That was one of the reasons why they did split in '86 after Aliens. I thought maybe when Titanic was done that Cameron would've learnt his lesson to trust the composer. But shooting down 90% of Horner's ideas, gives a sour taste in my mouth. Cameron knows film-making but doesn't understand music-making. It is a beginner's mistake not to think about music until the absolute last minute. Then they say they don't have money for it and chickened out with some cheap shit. Film-makers, please understand our craft, but we don't expect you to be experts. Our job is to make you feel comfortable and  that our job is to help supporting the story.

snippet.textDisplay:
the only thing i knew about the pre-production and world-building of avatar was Wayne Douglas Barlowe's involvement in some of the creature designs. i think when he's working science fiction, especially with sci-fi animals, he's very good at making alien creatures that still seem plausibly real, but sufficiently alien. just comparable enough in appearance or behavior for us to be able to compare it to real life wildlife without it being just a different colored horse or leopard (if you want to see what i mean, read his book expedition, or watch the fictional documentary Alien Planet based off said book.)
though if you look at Barlowe's concept art for Avatar from 2005, and compare it to when we see those same creatures in the film... all of them appear better in that art, to me at least. they're more alien, yet still like animals... i feel like some were simplified for the film. the concept art he has posted was from 4 years before the movie released, so its plausible the designs just changed, it WAS all conceptual. the main thing that feels different is they have more "normal" eyes and mouths, and some simplified details compared to their concept versions. it makes me wonder if those creature designs in the film were altered in the same way the music and culture ways to make them more.... recognizable? LESS alien?
also there's a creature in the concept art for Avatar that he has on his website, its nicknamed "Manticore" and best i can tell skimming the film's wiki there is no version of it in the film or reference to it anywhere, and i wonder if it got replaced with that animal that's a big 6 armed cat-like thing that looks like it has a mane. that predator that chases the main guy around in a scene early on and i think someone rides one into battle later. if that big cat-ish looking creature replaced this really unique and cool "Manticore" predator that Barlowe drew up... then that just feels like a waste. instead of using this wholly unique creature that looks like a cool alien apex predator like nothing on earth, lets just use this creature based off panthers and other large cats, one of the most common apex predators across 5 of the 7 continents.

Barlowe has done a lot of stuff, like the design for Remus Lupin's werewolf form in the 3rd harry potter film, some of the kaiju in Pacific Rim, and i think he did some designs for Aquaman but i don't know what specifically, and i'm sure there is plenty more.
the guy does great work, and its a shame if it goes to waste at times.

anyways, enough about creature designs, but man... the more i hear about all the work that went into this movie, the more i'm disappointed by it.... it feels like so much just got tossed to the wayside and what we ended up with is this pretty generic story that feels like we've seen it before... but now its with aliens and stuff.
i may not know a whole lot about music, but i still find the stuff you talk about in these videos fascinating. keep up the good work!
snippet.textOriginal:
the only thing i knew about the pre-production and world-building of avatar was Wayne Douglas Barlowe's involvement in some of the creature designs. i think when he's working science fiction, especially with sci-fi animals, he's very good at making alien creatures that still seem plausibly real, but sufficiently alien. just comparable enough in appearance or behavior for us to be able to compare it to real life wildlife without it being just a different colored horse or leopard (if you want to see what i mean, read his book expedition, or watch the fictional documentary Alien Planet based off said book.) 
though if you look at Barlowe's concept art for Avatar from 2005, and compare it to when we see those same creatures in the film... all of them appear better in that art, to me at least. they're more alien, yet still like animals... i feel like some were simplified for the film. the concept art he has posted was from 4 years before the movie released, so its plausible the designs just changed, it WAS all conceptual. the main thing that feels different is they have more "normal" eyes and mouths, and some simplified details compared to their concept versions. it makes me wonder if those creature designs in the film were altered in the same way the music and culture ways to make them more.... recognizable? LESS alien? 
also there's a creature in the concept art for Avatar that he has on his website, its nicknamed "Manticore" and best i can tell skimming the film's wiki there is no version of it in the film or reference to it anywhere, and i wonder if it got replaced with that animal that's a big 6 armed cat-like thing that looks like it has a mane. that predator that chases the main guy around in a scene early on and i think someone rides one into battle later. if that big cat-ish looking creature replaced this really unique and cool "Manticore" predator that Barlowe drew up... then that just feels like a waste. instead of using this wholly unique creature that looks like a cool alien apex predator like nothing on earth, lets just use this creature based off panthers and other large cats, one of the most common apex predators across 5 of the 7 continents. 

Barlowe has done a lot of stuff, like the design for Remus Lupin's werewolf form in the 3rd harry potter film, some of the kaiju in Pacific Rim, and i think he did some designs for Aquaman but i don't know what specifically, and i'm sure there is plenty more.
the guy does great work, and its a shame if it goes to waste at times.

anyways, enough about creature designs, but man... the more i hear about all the work that went into this movie, the more i'm disappointed by it.... it feels like so much just got tossed to the wayside and what we ended up with is this pretty generic story that feels like we've seen it before... but now its with aliens and stuff. 
i may not know a whole lot about music, but i still find the stuff you talk about in these videos fascinating. keep up the good work!

snippet.textDisplay: I think what they are all forgetting and what i hoped you also would talk about, is how most of the time film-music's main role is to hold the audiences hands and guide them to the films story. Most viewers have no musical background and really won't hear all the reasoning behind a score. It is all about pattern recognition. I think as composers we have to keep in mind that the music itself should remind the listener about something familiar, so that they get drawn into the world of the film. That is why their initial ideas would have never worked. While the reasoning behind it all might make sense on paper, it being something people never heard before would fail to hold the hand of the viewers. So yes that means giving up some cool idea's for your standard Hollywood/western sound. Yes, you can bring in some cool new ethnic elements or instruments  but you can't come up with a completely new genre unless it has something familiar, be it the instruments, be it the harmonic/melodic language. So while I agree with you that it is a pity that those original demo's might reflect the world of avatar better i don't think it would have ever worked for a Hollywood film.

Most viewers have no musical background and really won't hear all the reasoning behind a score. It is all about pattern recognition. I think as composers we have to keep in mind that the music itself should remind the listener about something familiar, so that they get drawn into the world of the film. That is why their initial ideas would have never worked. While the reasoning behind it all might make sense on paper, it being something people never heard before would fail to hold the hand of the viewers. So yes that means giving up some cool idea's for your standard Hollywood/western sound. Yes, you can bring in some cool new ethnic elements or instruments  but you can't come up with a completely new genre unless it has something familiar, be it the instruments, be it the harmonic/melodic language. So while I agree with you that it is a pity that those original demo's might reflect the world of avatar better i don't think it would have ever worked for a Hollywood film.
